fields:
{{c1::Autoimmune disease}}: Immune system cannot distinguish between self and non-self

{{c1::Chronic inflammatory diseases}}: Over activation of the immune system

Is it innate or adaptive immunity?

Higher organisms only {{c1::a}}
Pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs){{c1::i}}
Non-specific{{c1::i}}
T-lymphocytes {{c1::a}}
Monocytes{{c1::i}}
Polymorphonuclear leukocytes{{c1::i}}
Neutrophils{{c1::i}}
Barrier defenses{{c1::i}}
Antibodies {{c1::a}}
Why would you use an immunosupressant?
Autoimmune disease, Chronic inflammatory disease, Organ Transplant

Opportunistic Infections:{{c1::Infections that do not normally occur in patients with a normal immune system}}

Most {{c1::immune suppressant}} drugs increase the risk of opportunistic
infections
Immunosuppressants may also lower vaccine efficacy.

Which statement about
Immunosuppression is true?

1. It increases the risk of opportunistic infections
2. It only affects the adaptive immune system
3. It should be employed in patients with infections
4. Transplant recipients don’t need it
5. Vaccines are immunosuppressants

What sort of organ failure does it cause?

{{c1::Chronic Kidney Disease}}: Diabetes, glomerulonephritis, hypertension, others

{{c1::Chronic cirrhosis}}: Alcohol, Hepatitis C, NAFLD, autoimmune

{{c1::Acute liver failure}}: Paracetamol overdose, Hepatitis A, others....

Liver transplantation
Most commonly performed for complications of {{c1::cirrhosis}}, such as:
Hepatic encephalopathy:{{c1::confused thinking}}
Refractory ascites:{{c1::Buildup of fluid in the abdomen}}
{{c1::Variceal}} haemorrhage
Liver cancer

Transplant can be cadaveric or living related
Must be ABO {{c1::compatible}}

Complications of liver transplantation
Acute cellular rejection
Recognition of {{c1::allo}}antigens
Lymphocyte activation
Clonal expansion of lymphocytes

Corticosteroids

Hydrocortisone (cortisol) produced in the adrenal cortex
 
Essential for health – deficiency results in a disease: {{c1::Addisons disease}}

Excess endogenous hydrocortisone results in adisease: {{c1::Cushings syndrome}}

Secretion controlled by pituitary hormone: {{c1::ACTH}}

Is it a corticosteroid target?
Glucocorticoid receptors{{c1::y}}
Mineralocorticoid{{c1::n}}
Monocytes{{c1::y}}
Endothelial cells{{c1::y}}
B-Lymphocytes{{c1::n}}
T-Lymphocytes{{c1::y}}
Neutrophils{{c1::y}}

Is it an acute or chronic side effect?
Hypertension{{c1::a}}
Oppurtunistic Infections{{c1::a}}
Adrenal suppression{{c1::C}}
Muscle atrophy{{c1::c}}
Osteoporosis{{c1::c}}
Psychosis{{c1::a}}
Weight gain{{c1::a}}
Striae{{c1::c}}
Increased triglycerides{{c1::a}}
Diabetes{{c1::a}}
Hirsutism{{c1::a}}
Acne{{c1::a}}
Cataracts{{c1::c}}
Growth retardation{{c1::c}}

Side effects of corticosteroids mimic {{c1::Cushings Syndrome}}

{{c1::Topical}} administration minimizes systemic adverse effects allowing chronic use
With chronic {{c1::systemic}} administration, adverse effects outweigh benefits

Hirsutism=unwanted hair growth
Striae= Stretch marks

Topical corticosteroids: Uses
z Inflammatory skin diseases
z Asthma
z Inflammatory bowel disease – controlled ileal-release
budesonide
z Uveitis

Systemic corticosteroids: Uses
z Life-saving in severe asthma exacerbations
z Use coincided with reduction in mortality from ulcerative colitis – a form of
inflammatory bowel disease
z Vasculitis
z Inflammatory arthritis
z Blood cancers
z Glomerulonephritis
z Multiple sclerosis
z Vasculitis
z Autoimmune hepatitis

Which statement about corticosteroids is correct?

1. Anti-inflammatory effects are mediated by the mineralocorticoid receptor
2. They are hydrophilic and traverse plasma membranes poorly
3. They must be administered systemically
4. Their actions affect both innate and adaptive immune cells
5. Side effects are uncommon even with prolonged administration

Cyclosporine or Tacrolimus?

Binds FKBP {{c1::t}}
Fungal metabolite{{c1::c}}
Binds cyclophilin{{c1::c}}
Inhibits T cell activation{{c1::both}}
Macrolide antibiotic{{c1::t}}

How Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus inhibit T-cell activation

-Cyclosporine A and Tacrolimus inhibit {{c1::calcineurin}}
-The transcription factor {{c1::NFAT}} cannot be dephosphorylated
-{{c1::IL-2}} is not produced leading to inhibition of t-cell  activity

Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus
Major Uses:
Prevention of organ transplant {{c1::rejection}}
Autoimmune & Inflammatory diseases
{{c1::- Vasculitis
- Arthritis
- IBD
- Psoriasis
- Eczema}}(5)

Cyclosporine:

-{{c1::Unpredictable}} oral biovailability due to {{c1::Emulsion formulation}}

- {{c1::Narrow}} therapeutic index

Blood concentration monitoring essential

Side Effects:
Oppurtunistic infections
{{c1::Nephro}}toxicity
{{c1::Hyper}}tension
Gum {{c1::hyperplasia}}
{{c1::Skin}} cancer
Seizures
Neuropathy

Cyclosporine is metabolized by {{c1::CYP3A4}}.
Patients should not drink {{c1::grapefruit juice}}

Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus:

Have few adverse effects
Have a low therapeutic index
Block the binding of IL-2 to its receptor
Are considered "designer" drugs
Cause bone marrow suppression

Polyclonal Anti-Thymocyte Globulin

Developed by immunising rabbits with human thymocytes

{{c1::Gamma globulins}} purified from serum

Polyclonal mixture of antibodies reactive against lymphocyte expressed surface antigens

Administration results in profound killing of {{c1::host lymphocytes}}

{{c1::Profound}} immunosuppression – {{c1::loads of}} opportunistic infections

Effective treatment for {{c1::acute kidney transplant rejection}}

Monoclonal Anti IL-2 receptor antibodies

Drug names: {{c1::Daclizumab}} and {{c1::basiliximab}}

 IL-2 is a pivotal cytokine in the development of acquired
immune responses
 
Effective treatment for {{c1::acute rejection}}

{{c1::Less}} profound immunosuppression than polyclonal anti-
thymocyte globulin

{{c1::Less}} opportunistic infections

IBD: Histology

{{c1::Epithelium}} is ulcerated

{{c1::Lamina propria}} is infiltrated with acute and chronic inflammatory cells

Crypts have {{c1::abscesses}}


For extra points, where is the ulcer
Ulcer is the big crypt with the white outline

Thiopurines (immunosupressants) 

Mechanism of action:
Deplete {{c1::purine nucleotides}}

Inhibits:
- {{c1::DNA}} synthesis
- {{c1::RNA}} synthesis

Results in:
- Apoptosis of {{c1::activated lymphocytes}}
- Impaired cell-mediated immunity, specifically {{c1::adaptive}} cell-mediated immunity

{{c1::chronic}} Immunosuppression.


Azathioprine (A thiopurine)

Originally developed as an anti-leukemia drug
Pro-drug of {{c1::6-mercaptopurine}}

Has a {{c1::narrow}} therapeutic index
{{c1::oral}} administration
{{c1::slow}} onset of action

Is the side effect acute or chronic?
Opportunistic infections {{c1::b}}
Allergy: Fever, skin rash {{c1::a}}
EBV-associated lymphomas {{c1::c}}
Bone marrow suppression, esp. leukopenia {{c1::a}}
Pancreatitis {{c1::a}}
Liver injury {{c1::c}}

Azathiopurine dose is based on the patients levels of the enzyme {{c1::thiopurine methyltransferase}}

If there is low levels of this enzyme, Azathiourine is {{c1::more}} effective, but there are more {{c1::ADRs}} such as {{c1::myelosuppression}}


AZATHIOPURINE IS CONVERTED TO {{c1::6-MERCAPTOPURINE}} WHICH IS CONVERTED TO {{c1::6-THIOGUAMINE}}

Azathiprine is apparently a prototype
Leukopenia= Too little WBCs
EBV=Epstein Barr Virus
TPMT levels are genetic

Which statement is false? 
 Azathioprine is a pro-drug 
 Hereditary factors affect responses to thiopurines 
 Azathioprine does not cause significant immunosuppression 
 Thiopurines are administered orally 
 Patients full blood count should be monitored

Methotrexate:

Competitive analog of {{c1::folic acid}}
Blocks {{c1::dihydrofolate reductase}}
Prevents accumulation of {{c1::4H-folic acid}}
Blocks {{c1::purine}} biosynthesis
{{c1::S}}-phase cells most sensitive to methotrexate 

Causes:
Apoptosis of {{c1::activated lymphocytes}}
Inhibition of {{c1::neutrophil}} functions

Methotexate is given once weekly, why?
{{c1::Because it accumulates in cells}}


{{c1::oral, SC or IM}} Administration
SLow onset of action

Adverse effects
Bone marrow suppression which leads to {{c1::leukopenia}}
{{c1::Liver}} toxicity
Hypersensitivity {{c1::pneumonitis}}

Which statement is true about methotrexate? 
 Methotrexate blocks accumulation of dihydrofolate 
 It is structurally similar to purine nucleotides 
 Methotrexate can only be administered parenterally 
 Adverse effects include kidney damage 
 Administered once weekly

Monoclonal antibodies 
Advantages: 
 Highly {{c1::specific}} to their target 
 {{c1::Long}} duration of action 
 Most side effects are intrinsic ie extensions of the action of the drug at its target 
 New drug targets available 
    -{{c1::Extracellular}} proteins 
    -{{c1::Cell surface}} proteins 
 Big in immune-mediated disease and {{c1::oncology}}

Disadvantages 
 Expensive 
 Parenteral administration 
 Immuno{{c1::genicity }}
 Infusion reactions

{{c1::parenteral injection (Iv or sc)}} administration.

Extravasation dependant on {{c1::convection}} rather than {{c1::diffusion}}.
 
Transcytosis via {{c1::Fc}} receptors also relevant

Antigen binding takes place in {{c1::tissues}}

Eliminated by Receptor-mediated {{c1:: endocytosis}}
Intracellular catabolism by {{c1::lysosomal}} degradation
Protective effect of FcRn leading to some {{c1::recycling}}

If there is an anti-drug immune response:
Drug clearance is {{c1::faster}}
{{c1::loss}} of clinical efficacy
Increased risk of {{c1::allergic-type reactions}}
Immunogenicity=immune response can be mountded against it

TNF-alpha is central in Pathogenesis of many
diseases eg {{c1::IBD}}, {{c1::RA}}, {{c1::psoriasis}}

Which statement about monoclonal antibodies is false? 
 They are highly selective in binding their target 
 They are much more complex and costly to produce than small molecule drugs
  They must be administered parenterally (by injection) 
 They are metabolized by cytochromes P450 in the liver 
 They are dosed much less frequently than small molecule drugs

Etanercept 
 Soluble TNFalpha receptor {{c1::fusion}} protein 
 Affectively neutralises biological activity of TNF alpha
 Does not bind to {{c1::membrane}} associated TNF alpha
 Does not induce apoptosis of TNF alpha expressing cells 
 Effective in {{c1::RA}} but not {{c1::IBD}}
Is it a monoclonal antibody? {{c1::no}}

Infliximab
{{c1::mouse}}-human chimeric antibody
Binds to TNF-alpha expressing cells and induces {{c1::apoptosis}}
Why do they lose their effectiveness over time? {{c1::anti-inflixamab antibodies}}

Adverse Effects of TNFalpha Inhibitors:
Reactivation of {{c1::latent tuberculosis }} 
Increased risk of {{c1::opportunistic infections }}
Emergence of {{c1::Multiple Sclerosis}} 
Injection and infusion reactions

True statements concerning anti-TNF biologics include 
 Infliximab is a mouse-human chimeric anti-TNF monoclonal antibody 
 Patients should be screened for latent tuberculosis before starting any anti-TNF drug 
 Loss of response to anti-TNF biologics is often due to their immunogenicity 
 These drugs have proved highly beneficial in treating several chronic inflammatory diseases 
 All of the above

Anti-integrin biologics: Leukocyte extravasation inhibitors

Block the binding of {{c1::leukocyts}} to {{c1::vascular cell adhesion molecules}}

Natalizumab: anti-{{c1::α4}} integrin
Vedolizumab: specific anti-{{c1::α4β7}} integrin

Treat {{c1::IBD}} and {{c1::MS}}

Anti-cytokine biologics
Drug Name: Ustekinumab
Monoclonal {{c1::anti-p40}} subunit

Inhibits:
IL-{{c1::12/23}}

T/F this IL is:
Derived from hepatocytes {{c1::F}}
Elevated in only Rheumatic Arthrits{{c1::F}}
Stimulate Th1 and Th17 signalling{{c1::T}}

Derived from many types of
immune cells
Elevated in many inflammatory
diseases
Stimulate Th1 and Th17
signalling

Anti-B lymphocyte biologics
B cells involved in pathogenesis of RA
B cell malignancies ie lymphoma common
Rituximab
Anti-CD20 monoclonal
Blocks B cell activation
 Kills B cells by multiple
mechanisms

Mesalazine is used to treat IBD especially {{c1::ulcerative collitis}}
Another name for Mesalazine is {{c1::5-Aminosalicytic acid}}

Mesalazine is administered {{c1::orally}} or {{c1::rectally}}

The concentration of mesalazine achived in the large intestine is {{c1::10-30}}mmol/l this is a very {{c1::high concentration}}

It is {{c1::well}} tolerated

Corticosteroids are used sometimes in patients with {{c1::moderate to severe}} IBD

There are {{c1::many}} side effects associated with {{c1::long}} term use of corticosteroids

IMMUNOSUPPRESSANTS:
{{c1::Slow}}-acting 


Azathioprine/6-mercaptopurine 
 {{c1::Purine}} analogues 
 Decrease {{c1::nucleotide}} biosynthesis selectively in {{c1::lymphoid}} cells 
 S/Es: Bone marrow suppression, pancreatitis, allergy, lymphoma 

Methotrexate 
 {{c1::Folic acid}} analogue 
 Competitive inhibitor of {{c1::dihydrofolate reductase}}
  Induces apoptosis of activated {{c1::lymphocytes }}
 S/Es: Liver fibrosis, pneumonitis, bone marrow suppressions

TNFalpha 
 Pro-inflammatory {{c1::cytokine }}
 Produced by activated {{c1::macrophages}} in inflamed gut 

ANTI-TNFalpha drugs
Infliximab 
 Neutralizes {{c1::soluble}} and {{c1::membrane-associated}} TNFalpha
 Induces {{c1::apoptosis}} of cells expressing TNFalpha 

Highly effective in induces and maintaining responses in {{c1::IBD}} patients 


There is a loss of  response to Infliximab over time, why?
{{c1::Production of anti infliximab antibodies}}

Adverse effects of TNFalpha inhibitors
 Reactivation of latent {{c1::tuberculosis }}
 Increased risk of opportunistic infections 
 Emergence of {{c1::Multiple Sclerosis }}
 Injection and infusion reactions

Anti-integrin Biologics for IBD patients
Drug Name:{{c1::Vedolizumab (Entyvio)}}
 {{c1::Slow}} acting 
 {{c1::IV}} administered
 {{c1::Good}} efficacy 
 {{c1::Very few}} side effects

Anti-cytokine biologics in IBD
Drug Name: {{c1::Ustekinumab (Stelara)}}
 Combines IL-{{c1::12/23}}
 Derived from many types of immune cells
 Elevated in many inflammatory diseases
 Stimulate {{c1::Th1}} and {{c1::Th17}} signalling 
 Monoclonal anti-{{c1::p40}} subunit
 Good efficacy 
 Well tolerated 
 First dose {{c1::IV}} then SC

Vomiting

GI Irritation: 
Cytotoxic Drugs, Radiation & other GI irritants release 5-HT from the {{c1::enterochromaffin}} cells 
 Stimulation of the {{c::15-HT3}} Receptors present on vagal afferents
 Stimulation of {{c1::CTZ }}
 Vomiting

Vestibular Irritation:
-The vestibular apparatus generates impulses when body is rotated or {{c1::equilibrium}} is disturbed or when {{c1::ototoxic}} drugs act. 
-These impulses reach the vomiting centre mainly relayed by the {{c1::M}} and the {{c1::H1}} receptors. 
-Various sensory stimuli such as bad odour, ghastly sight, severe pain as well as fear cause {{c1::nausea}} and vomiting by direct stimulation of higher centres

Vomiting Mediators and Receptors
5-HT: an important mediator involved in such signals, many other mediators and peptides are also involved. 

The CTZ expresses a variety of receptors e.g. Histamine H{{c1::1}} , Dopamine D{{c1::2}} , Cholinergic M, Opioid u and the Serotonin 5-HT{{c1::3}} receptors, through which the emetic signals are relayed.

Anticholinergics, H1 Antihistamines, Neuroleptics, D2 Receptor Antagonist, 5-HT3 Receptor Antagonist, Others

 {{c1::D2 Receptor Antagonist}}: Domperidone, Metoclopramide 
 {{c1::Neuroleptics}}: Chlorpromazine, Haloperidol
 {{c1::Anticholinergics}}: Hyoscine, Dicyclomine 
 {{c1::Others}}: Dexamethasone, BZD, Cannabinoids
 {{c1::H1 Antihistamines}}: Promethazine, Cyclizine, Diphenhydramine, Cinnarizine
 {{c1::5-HT3 Receptor Antagonist}}: Ondansetron, Granisetron

Anticholinergics
Hyoscine is an effective drug for {{c1::motion sickness }}
 Blocks {{c1::muscarinic}} receptors
 suitable for short journeys
 blocks the conduction of nerve impulses across a cholinergic link pathway leading from the {{c1::vestibular apparatus}} to the vomiting centre. 
 anticholinergic side effects such as {{c1::dry mouth}} and {{c1::sedation}}

Neuroleptics 
prochlorpromazine 
-Potent {{c1::antiemetics}} 
-Block {{c1::D2}} receptors in the CTZ. 
-Broad spectrum antiemetic effect and is useful in 
 Drug induced and postanaesthetic {{c1::nausea}} and vomiting 
 Vomiting due to diseases: {{c1::gastroenteritis}}, migraine etc. 
 {{c1::Hyperemesis gravidarum}}
-Second line agents 
-Sedation++

D2 receptor antagonist: 
-Metoclopromide 
 It increases GI {{c1::peristalsis}} leading to increased gastric emptying 

 The tone of {{c1::lower oesophageal sphincter}} is increased 

 ADR 
     sedation, dizziness, movement disorders (extrapyramidal) 
     acute {{c1::dystonias}} eg spasmodic torticollis 
     {{c1::occulogyric}} crisis 
     Managed with antihistamines eg diphenhydramine 

 Long term use can cause {{c1::Parkinsonism}} (tardive dyskinesia) 

-Domperidone 
      Similar but does not cross BBB – fewer side effects but less             effective 
      Associated with long {{c1::QT}} Syndrome
Oculogyric crisis refers to spasms of extraocular muscles leading to tonic eye deviation

5-HT3 Receptor Antagonists

Very effective in treating {{c1::Cancer Chemotherapy/Radiotherapy}} induced vomiting 

It is effective in vomiting due to any cause  

Blocks the emetogenic impulses both at their peripheral origin and their central relay.  

It has no {{c1::DA}} blocking effects  

It is given {{c1::orally}} or {{c1::i.v}}  

Generally well tolerated and very few side effects  

Granisetron is {{c1::10}} times potent than Ondansetron

Constipation usually the result of {{c1::slow colonic}} transit (lazy bowel) 
 Intermittent constipation is best prevented with a {{c1::high fibr}}e diet, adequate fluid intake, regular exercise 

 Those not responding to the above measures should be medically evaluated before started on laxatives

Does it cause constipation?
Opioid analgesics? {{c1::yes}}
Cationic Drugs? {{c1::yes}}
Anionic Drugs? {{c1::its not in the lecture so we'll say no}}
NSAID Drugs? {{c1::Nah}}
Calcium Channel blockers {{c1::Yes}}
Cholinergic {{c1::No, anti-cholinergic}}

Bulk Forming Laxatives 

 Indigestible, hydrophilic colloids that absorb water, forming a bulky {{c1::emollient gel}} that distends the colon and promotes {{c1::peristalsis}} 

 Natural plant products: 
-{{c1::Psyllium}} husk 
-{{c1::Methylcellulose}} 

 Synthetic fibres – Polycarbophil 

 ADR of these preparations include {{c1::bloating of abdomen}}

Stool Softeners 
 Soften the stool material, permitting {{c1::water}} and {{c1::lipids}} to penetrate 

 They are administered {{c1::orally}} or {{c1::rectally}}. 

 Common agents
-Docusate (orally and as an enema) 
-{{c1::Glycerine}} suppository 

 Mineral oil is a clear, viscous oil which lubricates faecal material, retarding water absorption from the stool (for treating faecal impaction in {{c1::children}})

Osmotic Laxatives 
 Osmotic laxatives are soluble but {{c1::nonabsorbable}} compounds 
 -result in increased stool liquidity due to an increase in faecal fluid 

 Magnesium oxide – to be used with caution in patients with {{c1::renal}} impairment (may cause {{c1::hypermagnesemia}}) 

 Sorbitol & Lactulose – 
-Treatment of {{c1::chronic}} constipation 
-Metabolized by the colonic bacteria 
-May cause severe {{c1::flatus}} and {{c1::cramps}}

Motility stimulant 
 Prucalopride 
-{{c1::5HT4}} agonist 
-Stimulates colonic smooth muscle {{c1::contraction }}
When is it used? {{c1::The other treatments have failed}}
WHen should anti-diarrhoetic drugs NOT be used?
When there is stool in the diarrhoea

Opioid Agonists (for diarrhoea)

 These agents have significant constipating effects 

 Inhibition of {{c1::pre}}synaptic cholinergic nerves in {{c1::submucosal}} and {{c1::myenteric}} plexus and lead to increased colonic transit time. 
-Loperamide  
-{{c1::Diphenoxylate }}

 Less CNS effect than conventional opiates, why? {{c1::Doesn't usually cross the BBB}}

 At higher than recommended doses, CNS effects can occur 

 Codeine can also be used (morphine pro-drug)

Anti-cholinergics (for diarrhoea)

Atropine 

 Combined with opioids in certain pharmaceutical preparations
-Low dose 
-Uncertain benefit at such low doses 

What happnes at doses sufficient to inhibit diarrhoea? {{c1::Many bad side effects Dry mouth, tachycardia, sedation}}

Peptic Ulcer Disease:

Three areas where ulcers occur in it; {{c1::Esophagus}}(due to acid reflux), {{c1::stomach}} and{{c1::small intestine}} .

Most common symptom of PUD is {{c1::a gnawing pain}}

PUD: Pathogenesis 

Normal defences against ulcers T/F

Peristalsis {{c1::F}}
Mucus {{c1::t}}
Cell renewal {{c1::t}} 
Blood flow {{c1::t}}
Secretin {{c1::f}}
Cytokines  {{c1::f}}
Bicarbonate layer  {{c1::t}}
Sphincters  {{c1::f}}
Prostaglandins {{c1::t}}
Cell renewal  {{c1::t}}

Pathogenic Factors:

Most Common:
{{c1::helicobacter}} infection and {{c1::NSAIDs}}

Least Common: 
Excess {{c1::Acid}}


ULCER OCCURS WHEN {{c1::PATHOGENIC}} FACTORS OUTWEIGH {{c1::DEFENSES}}

Helicobacter {{c1::Pylori}}

Gram {{c1::negative}} bacillus
Causes {{c1::Chronic Gastritis}}

Present in most patients with a non-NSAID linked {{c1::duodenal}} Ulcer

H. pylori infection is detectable before the occurrence of DU and appears to be a risk factor for the disorder.

Eradication of H. pylori prevents disease recurrence

PUD and NSAIDs

NSAIDs decrease protective {{c1::prostaglandin}} production in the stomach (systemic effect)

Maybe additional direct irritant effect (local effect)

What is a Gastrinoma?
What disease causes Gastrinomas?
How can Gastrinomas cause Peptic Ulcers?

Gastrin secreting tumour
Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome
Gastrin is acidic and excess acid causes ulcer.

The Three Gastric Acid Secretagogues are
{{c1::Histamine}}: Produced by {{c1::M}} cells
{{c1::Ach}}: Produced by {{c1::Cholinergic}} Nerves
{{c1::Gastrin}}: Delivered via Blood vessels

Inhibition Of Gastric Acid:

ANTACIDS:

-{{c1::Neutralizes}} Gastric Acids and {{c1::raises}} pH

-Contains:
       {{c1::Magnesium}} salts,which can cause diarrhoea
       {{c1::Aluminium}} salts, which can cause constipation
        {{c1::Sodium Hydroxide}}
Most preparations use various anatacids together.

H2 receptor antagonists 

 {{c1::Competitive}} antagonists of the receptor 

 Inhibit {{c1::basal acid}} secretion 

 Decrease acid secretion in response to 
- Histamine 
- Gastrin 
- Acetylcholine 
Why? {{c1::All have an effect on m cells}}

 Examples 
- {{c1::Cimetidine}} 
- {{c1::Ranitidine}}
Very Effective

Proton pump inhibitors

Irreversible inhibition of the {{c1::H+/K+-ATPase (the proton pump}}) 

 Final common pathway of basal and induced acid secretion 

Are administered as {{c1::prodrugs}}

Weak bases, accumulate in the acid environment of the canaliculi of the stimulated parietal cell where they are activated

Examples: {{c1::Omeprazole, lansoprazole, rabeprazole}} (3)
Antacid example: Maalox: Each 5 ml of oral solution contains: Aluminium hydroxide 175mg Magnesium hydroxide 200mg

Cimetidine and ranitidine 

 {{c1::High}} oral bioavailability 
 Usually given twice daily 
 Low side effect profile :{{c1::Diarrhoea}} and {{c1::Rash}} 
 Available OTC 
 Renal excretion – reduce dose in renal insufficiency

Cimetidine inhibits {{c1::CYP450 }}
 Drug interactions (Higher {{c1::Warfarin}} and {{c1::TCA}} levels)

Omeprazole 
 Best taken 30 minutes before a meal 
 Also IV 

 Adverse effects are {{c1::Very well}} tolerated: 
 {{c1::Diarrhoea }}
 {{c1::Allergic skin rash }}

 S-enantiomer available also (esomeprazole) 
 Metabolized by {{c1::CYP2C19}}
Proton Pump Inhibitors have a half life of 1-1.5 hours, yet their duration of action is 24-36 hours, how?

Canalicular trapping by protonation (weak base in an acidic pH) 
 Irreversible inhibition of H+/K+ ATPase so requires Requires new pump synthesis to start secreting acid again.

The recurrent rate of PUD is > {{c1::30%}}

Requires long-term {{c1::H2RA}} or {{c1::PPI}} therapy

 Expense 
 Inconvenience 
 Potential for side effects

1. Antacids block gastric acid secretion 
2. Cimetidine inhibits the final common pathway for acid secretion 
3. Acid inhibition causes malabsorption 
4. Omeprazole has a long plasma half life, explaining its 24h duration of action 
5. Omeprazole is trapped in the parietal cell and irreversibly inhibits the proton pump

5. Omeprazole is trapped in
the parietal cell and
irreversibly inhibits the
proton pump

H. pylori eradication

{{c1::multi}} drug regimens

Answer Penicillin tolerant, penecillin allergic or both to treatrment options

Metronidazole {{c1::PCN allergic}}
Clarithromycin {{c1::both}}
Amoxicillin {{c1::PCN tolerant}}
PPI {{c1:: Both}}

7-14 days
{{c1::80-90}}% eradication rate.

 Variable efficacy 
 Gradual increase in prevalence of drug-resistant strains

NSAIDs  
Aspirin and Non-aspirin anti-inflammatory pain killers 
 Used to treat pain, especially arthritic pain 

 Block the actions of {{c1::cyclo-oxygenase}} 
 {{c1::↓}} levels of PGE2 
 {{c1::↓}} Mucous and bicarbonate secretion 
 {{c1::increase}} acid production

To mitigate this you use 
Misoprostol

 Stable analogue of {{c1::PGE2}} 
 Oral – produces high concentration at gastro-duodenal mucosa 
 Mitigates harmful effects of NSAIDs on {{c1::PG}} production in stomach 
 Decreases rate of NSAID-induced {{c1::ulceration }}
 Usefulness limited by  {{c1::Diarrhoea}}  Effects on {{c1::cervix}}

1. Peptic ulcers can be caused by an infection with H pylori 
2. Eradication of H pylori with 2 antibiotics and a PPI is 100% effective 
3. Misoprostol blocks prostaglandin receptors 
4. NSAIDs decrease gastro-protective prostaglandins 
5. PPIs are available over the counter

Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease 
 Incompetence of {{c1::lower oesophageal sphincter}} (obesity, drugs, heredity…….) 
 Reflux of acidic gastric contents into lower oesophagus
 Heartburn 

 Complications 
    -{{c1::Stricture }}
    -{{c1::Barretts oesophagus & cancer}}

Diagnosis: 
 {{c1::Heartburn}} symptoms 
 Reflux oesophagitis 

 Gold standard test
 -24 hour oesophageal pH
 -{{c1::De Meester}} score

GORD: Treatment 
 Prevent acid reflux 
 Weight loss, drug avoidance, elevate head of bed etc 
 Surgical {{c1::fundoplication }}
 Increase tone of {{c1::LOS }}

 Medical 
 Suppress gastric acidity (requires chronic therapy) 
 {{c1::PPI}} or {{c1::H2RA}}

Anaphylaxis
Severe acute allergic, {{c1::IgE}}-mediated,immediate {{c1::hypersensitivity}} reactions
Accounts for 1% A&E visits
Life-threatening (5000-10,000 deaths per year in US)

Commonest allergens
{{c1::z Insect stings
z Foods
z Drugs
z Protein drugs (such as infliximab)
z Radiocontrast agents}} (5)

Milder allergic reactions
Confined to body surfaces
{{c1::Sites of contact}} with allergens
Very common
 Symptoms trivial and recurrent

Commonest allergens
{{c1::Pollen
z House dust mite dander
z Latex}} (3)

Examples of Allergic reactions:

Food allergy
Cause:{{c1::Peanut, shell fish, kiwi, strawberry..........}}
Rxn; GI upset to {{c1::Anaphylaxis}}

Asthma
Cause: {{c1::House dust mite dander, pollen.......}}
Rxn: {{c1::Wheezing}}, can be life threatening

Allergic rhinitis
Cause: {{c1::Fungal spores...}}
Rxn: {{c1::Nasal congestion, mild}}

Drug allergy
Cause: {{c1::PCN.......}}
Rxn: Rash to {{c1::Anaphylaxis}}

Contact dermatitis
Cause: {{c1::Latex.....}}
Rxn: {{c1::Rash}}

Hypersensitivity type I:

{{c1::IgE}} anti-bodies binds to the allergen, IgE corss links allergen with mast cell by binding onto the {{c1::Fc}} receptor.  The mast cell releases {{c1::histamine}} and eicanosoids such as {{c1::Lymphotoxins}} and {{c1::Prostoglandins}}

This reaction is called {{c1::degranulation}}

Histamine

Basic {{c1::amine}}
Stored in {{c1::mast}} cell granules
 Acts on specific histamine receptors H1, H2.... which are {{c1::G protein couples}} receptors

 H1 receptors present on
-{{c1::Bronchial}} smooth muscle – contraction
- {{c1::Endothelial}} cells – vasodilatation & vascular permeability
- {{c1::Vomiting}} centres in brain

Hypersensitivity type I reactions

Anaphylactic or immediate {{c::1hypersensitivity}} reaction
Develops only in genetically susceptible individuals
Mediated by allergen-specific {{c1::IgE}} antibodies
Central role of local histamine release in mild allergic reactions

Increased capillary permeability which causes {{c1::Wheal}} and {{c1::urticarial (hives)}}

Vasodilatation which causes {{c1::Erythema}}

Itch caused by {{c1::Sensory nerve irritation}}

Anaphylaxis: Clinical presentation 

{{c1::5-60}} minutes after exposure to allergen

{{c1::Urticaria}} and {{c1::angioedema}} due to Capillary leakage of plasma

Bronchospasm causing wheezing due to {{c1::Histamine}}-induced {{c1::bronchoconstriction}}

{{c1::Hypo}}tension and CV collapse due to {{c1::Hypo}}volemia, myocardial depression

Vomiting, diarrhea

Concerning allergy, which statement is false?

1. Allergic reactions are antigen-specific
2. IgE triggers histamine release from mast cells
3. Histamine acts on H1 receptors to cause bronchodilatation and vasoconstriction
4. Allergic diseases range from mild everyday symptoms to life-threatening emergencies
5. Can to diagnosed by skin prick testing

Epinephrine

Stimulates:
{{c1::beta2}} adrenoceptors – bronchodilation
{{c1::beta1}} adrenoceptors – increased cardiac contractility
{{c1::alpha}} adrenoceptors - vasoconstriction

Life saving
No absolute contraindication
Needs to be administered {{c1::rapidly}}

Anaphylaxis after Epinephrine:
Anti-histamines
Drug Name: {{c1::Diphenhydramine}}
{{c1::H1}} receptor inverse agonist
Administered {{c1::IV}} or {{c1::orally}}
Continue for duration of symptoms
Inhibit {{c1::vasodilation}}, vascular leakage and bronchospasm

Beta 2 adrenoceptor agonists
Given to {{c1::Wheezing}} patients
Drug Name: {{c1::Salbutamol}}
{{c1::Nebulised}} administration
Not a substitute for epinephrine


2nd phase of {{c1::anaphylaxis}} often occurs 8-72 hours after initial symptoms
Markedly inflammatory
Mediated in part by {{c1::eicosanoids}} and {{c1::cytokines}}

Corticosteroids
Inhibit the 2nd phase
Must be administered {{c1::early}}
Drug Name: {{c1::Methylprednisolone }}
Administered IV, high dose

Agressive fluid {{c1::resuscitation}}
Airway Management

Anaphylaxis
1. Is difficult to diagnose
2. Should only be treated in a hospital setting
3. Causes severe hypertension
4. Requires immediate administration of anti-histamines and corticosteroids
5. Should be treated with IM adrenaline

Atopic diseases
Skin: {{c1::eczema}}
Airways: {{c1::asthma}}
GIT: {{c1::food allergy}} (differentiate disease from common use of this term)
Eyes: {{c1::conjunctivitis}}
Nose: {{c1::allergic rhinitis}}

Drugs for atopy

Corticosteroids

 Administered at time/season of symptoms

 Slow-acting – must be used {{c1::prophylactically}}

 Inhibit recruitment of {{c1::immune cells eg mast cells, lymphocytes etc}}

 Topical use minimizes systemic exposures
z Nasal spray
z Cream/ointment
z Eye drops 


Drug Name: {{c1::Fluticasone, triamcinolone, beclomethasone}}

Structural modification of {{c1::hydrocortisone}} to
{{c1::increase}} lipophilicity
{{c1::increase}} first-pass metabolism
Glucocorticoid potency > mineralocorticoid

z ADR:
z Some systemic exposure even with topicals
z Skin – {{c1::thinning}} with chronic use

Mast cell stabilizers
Drug Names: {{c1::Cromolyn sodium}} and {{c1::nedocromil}}
z Inhibit {{c1::Cl}} channel on mast cells, and others
z Prevents mast cell {{c1::degranulation}} and {{c1::histamine}} release
z Ineffective once that has already happened
z Used {{c1::prophylactically}}

Route of administration
z {{c1::Inhalation}}: Allergic asthma
z {{c1::Nasal spray}}: Allergic rhinitis
z {{c1::Ophthalmic drops}}: Allergic conjunctivitis
z {{c1::Oral}}: Mastocytosis

Anti-histamines: H1 receptor partial agonists:

First Generation
Drug Name: {{c1::diphenhydramine, chlorpheniramine}}
z Lipop{{c1::hilic}}, cross BBB
z Act as “{{c1::inverse agonists}}”
z Drug that binds to the same receptor as an agonist but induces a pharmacological response opposite to that of the agonist

Used for
z {{c1::Anaphylaxis}}
z Nausea and vomiting

Adverse effects
z {{c1::Sedation}}
z {{c1::Dry mouth}}

Second generation:
Drug Names: {{c1::Cetirizine}}, {{c1::loratadine}}, {{c1::fexofenadine}}
z Lipo{{c1::phobic}}, don’t cross BBB
z Additional anti-inflammatory effects

Uses:
z {{c1::Allergic rhinitis}} (↓ sneezing, rhinorrhoea)
z {{c1::Urticaria}}

Orally administered

 Available OTC

Why Don't second-gen Anti-histamines cause sedation? {{c1::They don't cross the blood brain barrier}}
What was the name of the first non-sedating anti-histamine that got pulled due to suddden cardiac deaths?

Topical calcineurin inhibitors
{{c1::Tacrolimus}} (FK506) ointment
z Inhibits production of {{c1::IL-2}} by activated T lymphocytes

Uses:
z Atopic eczema dependent on {{c1::corticosteroids}}

 ADR:
z {{c1::Burning sensation in skin}}
z Possibly {{c1::lymphoma}}

Which statement about anti-histamines is
false?

1. Diphenhydramine is a H1 receptor antagonist
2. Diphenhydramine crosses the blood brain barrier
3. Loratadine does not cross the blood brain barrier
4. Terfenadine can be subject to a clinically significant drug-drug interaction
5. Many anti-histamines are available over the counter
{{c1::IgE}} binds to an Allergen, then {{c1::IgE}} binds to the {{c2::FC}} receptor on the mast cell, causing the release of {{c3::Histamine}}
Epinephrine stimulates {{c1::vasoconstriction}} on alpha-adrenoreceptors, {{c1::increased cardiac contractility}} on beta-1 receptors and {{c1::bronchodilation}} on beta-2 adrenoceptors
For Atopy, corticosteroids should be administered {{c1::prophylactally}} as they are slow acting, and {{c1::topically}} to minimize systemic exposure

Corticosteroids such as fluticasone, triamcinolone, beclomethasone are structurally modified {{c1::hydrocortisone}} and they have high {{c1::lipophilicity}}, high {{c1::first-pass metabolism}} and are more potent at {{c1::glucocorticoid}} receptors
Mast cell stabilizers inhibit {{c1::sodium channels}} on mast cells which prevent {{c1::degranulation}} and {{c1::histamine}} release.
1st generation  anti-histamines are lipo{{c1::phillic}}and they act as {{c1::inverse agonists}} (effect on receptor)
Where is the effect of a mild allergic reaction felt?
At the site of contact with the allergen

Food allergy, Asthma, Allergic Rhinitis, Drug Allergy, Contact dermatitis

Because 1st cross the blood brain barrier

Inflammation on the inside of the nose due to an allergen

Traditional attenuated virus

{{c1::2.}} The cultured virus is used to infect monkey cells
{{c1::1}}.Pathogenic virus is isolated from a patient and grown in human cultured 
{{c1::4.}} The virus no longer grows well in human cells and can be used in a vaccine
{{c1::3}} The virus acquires many mutations that allow it to grow well in  monkey cells
With recombinant DNA techniques, attenuation can be achieved by removing the {{c1::virulence}} part of pathogen, but leaving behind the {{c1::receptor binding protein}} and {{c1::core proteins}}

What sort of vaccine is it?

MMR {{c1::LAV}}
HEP B {{c1::SUB/CON}}
Passed Through cell cultures {{c1::LAV}}
HEP A {{c1::Inactivated}}

{{c1::Antigen}} provides specificity of response to adaptive immunity

{{c1::Adjuvant}} provides innate immune activity to boost adaptive immunity

Adjuvants bind to {{c1::Toll-like}} receptors on {{c1::antigen presenting}} cells or it can be {{c1::phagocytosed}}

Inflammasomes induce production of {{c1::cytokines}}

{{c1::APC}} presents the antigen which activates the immune response

Which immune response

Slow and not strong{{c1::primary}}

Fast and Strong {{c1::secondary}}

Reasons for inability to develop effective
vaccines: HIV

z Lack of {{c1::natural immunity}} to HIV
z {{c1::Variability}} of HIV types
z Lack of correlates of protective immunity
z Lack of an {{c1::animal model}} that reliably predicts vaccine efficacy in humans

HPV is a common STI
Infection at sexual debut
Most infected persons clear
HPV infection
Chronic HPV16 infection causes certain cancers:
{{c1::z Cervical
z Anal
z Penile
zHead and neck}} (4)

1.{{c1::APC}} takes up antigen 
2. {{c1::T helper cell}} exposed to antigen
3. {{c1::Naive}} T and B lymphocytes activated
4.{{c1::B-cells}} make antibodies, {{c1::T-cells}} kill the infected cells
5. {{c1::memory b-cells, memory t-cells and memory helper t-cells}}(3) stay behind
Who did the experiment of smallpox and cowpox?
How many laboratories in the world hold smallpox?

In traditional vaccines, virus is isolated from{{c1::humans}} and is used to infect {{c1::animal}} cells, the virus acquires many mutations that do not allow it to grow in {{c1::human}} cells anymore.
What are the three parts of a virus DNA?
With recombinant DNA techniques the {{c1::virulence}} gene of the virus is deleted.
In a live attenuated vaccine the {{c1::virus}} is selected. It is passed through tissue cultures and a {{c2::weakened strain}} of the virus is used.
Give an example of a live attenuated vaccine
Who should a live attenuated vaccine not be given to?
In an inactivated vaccine, a {{c1::bacterial}} or {{c1::viral}} strain is isolated, it is {{c1::inactivated}} using heat or chemicals.
Give an example of an inactivated vaccine
What is different about a subunit/conjugated vaccine, compared to the rest?
Only the part of pathogen that provokes an immune response is used
What sort of immune response does an antigen evoke?
What sort of immune response does an adjuvant evoke?
What type of cell takes up the vaccine?
What sort of diseases are affected by herd immunity?
Diseases that spread from human to human contact.
Give some reasons why HIV is unable to be vaccinated against?

Lack of natural immunity against it
Variability of HIV types
Lack of correlates of protective immunity 
Lack of an animal model that reliably predicts vaccine efficacy in humans
Administration of antibodies from an exposed donor specific to the infectious agent.
What is the name of the vaccine for HPV?

Asthma is common: affects up to {{c1::10%}} of children
Wheezing due to airflow {{c1::limitation}}
Is episodic , meaning that airflow {{c1::limitation}} is {{c1::reversible}}
Triggers
{{c1::z Allergens
z Exercise
z Cold air
z Virus infections}} (4)

Limitation due to narrow bronchi
Goes from mild and occasional, to serious and persistent

In asthma, the airflow limitation arises as a result of the {{c1::bronchi}} being too narrow.
It is felt mainly at {{c1::exhalation}} as the positive pressure in the chest cavity when the {{c1::diaphragm}} and the {{c1::intercostal muscles}} relax constricts the {{c1::bronchii}} even further.

Lungs full and diaphragm flattened

Exhalation much slower in asthma

Causes of asthma
1. Allergic effect: {{c1::Mast}} cells, that release {{c1::histamine}} which constrict bronchial smooth muscle cells.

2. Neurological cause:{{c1::Vagus}} nerve acts on bronchial smpoth muscle cells through the neurotransmitter {{c1::Ach}}

FEV1 stands for {{c1::forced expiratory volume in 1second}}

During an asthma attack the FEV1 can decrease to as low as {{c1::75%}} (% of normal fev1)

Phase 1 asthma attack, Mast cell releasing histamine or Vagus nerve problem

Phase 2: CHronic {{c1::inflammation}}: Mast cells, eosinophils, neutrophils etc. infiltrate the bronchial {{c1::submucosa}} and {{c1::lamina propria}} which narrows the airway even more.
CD4+ T lymphocytes contribute to the inflammation

COPD, {{c1::COAD}}, {{c1::chronic bronchitis}}, {{c1::emphysema}}
 Almost universally linked with {{c1::cigarette smoking}}
{{c1::Irreversible}} damage to airways

Airflow limitation
Susceptibility to lower respiratory tract infections
Loss of lung function

Emphysema
Loss of {{c1::alveoli}} in centrilobar or {{c1::acinar}} area.
Oxygen and gas exchange is compromise, chronically {{c1::hypoxemic}}

Salbutamol and terbutaline are selective beta 2 {{c1::agonists}}

How much of the drug (cannisters being measurement) suggests the treatment of asthma is inadequate? {{c1::more than one}}

SHould only be used for bouts of asthmatic symptoms, if used regularly it may {{c1::lower effectiveness}} or increase {{c1::airway hyper responsivenss}}

Side effects
{{c1::z Tremor
z Tachycardia
z Nausea
z Light-headedness}} (4)

side effects mostly related to stimulation of Beta1 receptors in
CVS, would need to take a lot tho for this to happen

{{c1::salmeterol}} is a long acting b-adrenoceptor agonist
Has a {{c1::slower}} onset of action
It is not used for {{c1::acute}} symptoms

MUSCARINIC RECEPTOR ANTAGONISTS
Anticholinergic
Target is {{c1::vagally}}-mediated, acetylcholine-dependent
{{c1::parasympathetic}}(type of neuron) airway smooth muscle tone
Inhibits muscarinic receptors
 Example: ipratropium bromide
T/F More useful in asthma than COPD {{c1::false}}
T/F Inhaled {{c1::True}}
T/F Many clinically significant side effects {{c1::False}}

Methylxanthines
{{c1::Phosphodiesterase}} inhibitors
Examples:{{c1::Theophylline}} (oral) and {{c1::Aminophylline}} (IV)
Cause relaxation of bronchial smooth muscle
May have other mechanisms of action
Anti-inflammatory effects


Side effects
Narrow therapeutic index
{{c1::Nausea}}
Gastro-oesophageal reflux
{{c1::Tachycardia}}
Agitation
This is for when the patient cannot take any other medication whatsoever, it is shit compared to the others
Why does Albuterol(salbutamol) and ipratropium have an additive effect on their change in FEV1?
Two different mechanisms of action producing the same effect

Corticosteroid treatment in asthma patients is primarily used as prophylactic {{c1::anti-inflammatory}} to prevent the {{c1::2nd phase }} of an asthma attack.

They are taken prophylactically because corticosteroids are relatively {{c1::slow}} acting


{{c1::Glucocorticoid}} receptors 
 Innate immune cells such as  {{c1::Monocytes}} and {{c1::macrophages}}
 Adaptive immune cells

{{c1::Glucocorticoid}} receptors 
Innate immune cells: Monocytes, {{c1::macrophages}}
Adaptive immune cells: {{c1::T lymphocytes}}
Non-immune cells: {{c1::Endothelial cells}}

 Cough

Osteoporosis, Cataracts, Glaucoma,

Corticosteroid use in asthma and COPD T/F

 By inhalation {{c1::true}}
 Often combined with inhaled E2-adrenoceptor agonist {{c1::true}}
 Slow onset of action (hours){{c1::True}}
 Used for immediate symptom relief {{c1::False, is used prophylactilly}}
 Use after phase 1 part of attacks {{c1::true, still before phase 2}}

Systemically:
 Only used orally {{c1::False can be used IV}}

During an asthma attack, leukotrienes contribute to the {{c1::inflammaotry}} process. But they also further constrict the bronchial smooth muscle by acting on the {{c1::CysLT}} receptor.

Lukasts
{{c1:: Inhibit}} these receptors expressed on respiratory epithelium and infiltrating leukocytes
Improve airflow in both early and late phases
{{c1::Orally}} administered
Well tolerated
Example: {{c1::Montelukast}}
Slow acting: used to prevent attacks
Lukasts quicker acting than corticosteroid, but shorter lasting

Anti-IgE therapy of asthma
In some patients asthma triggers are {{c1::allergic}}

Anti-IgE treatment may be considered if:
-Moderate-to-severe {{c1::persistent}} asthma
-Asthma symptoms are inadequately controlled with inhaled
glucocorticoids
-A total serum IgE level is between {{c1::30}} and 1500 international units/mL, which is the range over which the drug can reduce enough free IgE to ensure a therapeutic effect
-Allergic sensitization demonstrated by positive skin testing or in vitro testing for allergen-specific IgE to an allergen that is present year-round e.g. {{c1::house dust mites, animal danders, cockroaches, or molds}}



{{c1::Omalizumab}} is a recombinant humanized anti-IgE antibody

Used in selected asthmatic patients 
Results in marked fall in serum IgE 
 May be useful also in other IgE-mediated diseases eg {{c1::recurrent anaphylaxis}}
